definitions: mentally pictured or conceived as a future possibility or outcome
having been planned or designed with a specific purpose in mind
examples: The envisioned project exceeded all expectations
She described her envisioned future in vivid detail
The envisioned changes will transform the company
Their envisioned solution addressed every problem

definitions: concerning or involving biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions
examples: The enzymatic reaction occurred rapidly at body temperature
Enzymatic processes break down complex molecules

definitions: existing or continuing for only a very short time before disappearing
examples: The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms captivates millions
Fame proved to be ephemeral for the young artist

definitions: relating to long poems about heroic deeds and adventures
remarkably large in scale, scope, or degree; extraordinary
examples: The epic poem told of ancient battles
Homer's epic tales shaped Western literature
Their epic journey crossed three continents
The concert was an epic three-hour performance

definitions: devoted to sensual enjoyment, especially of good food and drink
having luxurious tastes or habits especially in eating and drinking
examples: His epicurean lifestyle focused on sensory pleasures
The epicurean philosophy valued refined enjoyment
The epicurean feast delighted all the guests
She had epicurean tastes in wine and cuisine

definitions: relating to a disease affecting many people at the same time
spreading rapidly and extensively by infection among many individuals
examples: Epidemic cholera devastated the population
The epidemic outbreak required immediate response
Epidemic proportions of obesity concern health officials
Violence reached epidemic levels in the region

definitions: concerning the study of disease patterns, causes, and effects in populations
examples: The epidemiological study tracked infection rates
Epidemiological data revealed surprising patterns

definitions: concerning or caused by the neurological disorder characterized by seizures
having epilepsy or experiencing seizures from this condition
examples: The epileptic seizure lasted several minutes
Epileptic symptoms vary between patients
The epileptic patient required daily medication
Her epileptic condition was well controlled

definitions: concerning or governed by bishops in the Christian church hierarchy
examples: The episcopal authority governed the diocese
Episcopal traditions date back centuries

definitions: happening at irregular intervals; not continuous or steady
consisting of separate incidents or events like episodes in a story
examples: His episodic headaches worried the doctor
The patient showed episodic memory loss
The episodic structure made the novel easy to read
Television series often use episodic storytelling

definitions: concerning the nature, validity, and limits of knowledge and justified belief
examples: The epistemic foundations of science require scrutiny
Epistemic uncertainty affects all human understanding

definitions: relating to or consisting of letters or correspondence between people
examples: The epistolary novel unfolded through fictional letters
Her epistolary style created intimate character portraits

definitions: giving one's name to something; named after a particular person
examples: The band's eponymous album became their biggest hit
Shakespeare's eponymous heroes dominate their plays

definitions: being the same in quantity, size, degree, or value
having the same rights, status, or opportunities as others
having the ability or resources to meet a challenge
examples: The two sides are equal in length
Equal amounts were distributed to everyone
All citizens deserve equal treatment under law
The company promotes equal opportunities
She proved equal to the difficult task
The teams were equal in skill

definitions: relating to or located near the earth's equator line
examples: Equatorial regions experience consistent daylight hours
The equatorial climate remains hot year-round

definitions: concerning horses or horsemanship in general
relating to the sport or skill of riding horses
examples: The equestrian statue dominated the square
Equestrian activities require special facilities
She excelled in equestrian competitions
The equestrian center offers riding lessons

definitions: at equal distances from two or more points or places
examples: The three cities are equidistant from the capital
Place markers at equidistant intervals

definitions: having all sides of equal length, especially describing triangles
examples: An equilateral triangle has three equal sides
The equilateral design ensures perfect symmetry

definitions: of, relating to, or characteristic of horses or the horse family
examples: The equine veterinarian specialized in racehorses
Equine therapy helps children with disabilities

definitions: provided with necessary tools, supplies, or equipment for a purpose
having the necessary abilities or qualities to deal with something
examples: The laboratory is equipped with modern instruments
Their kitchen came fully equipped
She's well equipped to handle the crisis
Students aren't equipped for these challenges

definitions: treating everyone fairly and equally; just and reasonable
examples: The judge sought an equitable solution for both parties
Equitable distribution of resources prevents conflict

definitions: equal in value, amount, function, or meaning to something else
having the same effect or function though not identical in form
examples: One mile is equivalent to 1.6 kilometers
The two degrees are considered equivalent
This word has no equivalent in English
The military equivalent would be a colonel

definitions: open to more than one interpretation; deliberately ambiguous or unclear
of uncertain nature or classification; questionable or suspicious
examples: His equivocal response left everyone confused
The politician gave equivocal answers
The test results were equivocal
Evidence remains equivocal about the treatment

definitions: in a vertical position; standing straight up
rigidly upright or straight in bodily posture
examples: The monument stands erect against the skyline
Keep the poles erect during assembly
She walked with an erect posture
The soldier stood erect at attention

definitions: capable of becoming rigid or upright, especially describing body tissue
examples: Erectile tissue responds to blood flow changes
The bird's erectile crest signals aggression

definitions: designed for efficiency and comfort in the working environment
examples: The ergonomic chair reduced back pain significantly
Ergonomic keyboards prevent repetitive strain injuries

definitions: worn away by wind, water, or other natural agents over time
gradually destroyed, diminished, or weakened
examples: The eroded coastline retreated several meters
Eroded rock formations created spectacular landscapes
Their eroded trust never fully recovered
The company's eroded market share worried investors

definitions: tending to erode or capable of causing erosion gradually
examples: Erosive forces shaped the canyon over millennia
The erosive effects of acid rain damage buildings

definitions: relating to or tending to arouse sexual desire or excitement
examples: The museum displayed erotic art from ancient cultures
Her erotic poetry pushed social boundaries

definitions: straying from the proper course or correct path
deviating from accepted standards of conduct or morality
examples: An errant golf ball broke the window
The errant missile missed its target
The errant knight sought redemption
Her errant behavior disappointed her parents

definitions: not even or regular in pattern or movement; unpredictable
examples: His erratic driving frightened the passengers
The patient showed erratic heartbeat patterns

definitions: wrong or incorrect; based on false information or mistaken beliefs
examples: The report contained erroneous data about sales
His erroneous assumption led to failure

definitions: made or used as an inferior substitute for something else
examples: The ersatz coffee tasted nothing like the real thing
They served ersatz leather that fooled nobody

definitions: former; belonging to or occurring in an earlier time
examples: His erstwhile allies turned against him
The erstwhile champion struggled to compete

definitions: having or showing great knowledge gained from study and reading
examples: The erudite professor impressed everyone with her insights
His erudite commentary enriched the discussion

definitions: breaking out or bursting forth suddenly and violently
examples: The eruptive volcano threatened nearby villages
Her eruptive temper made her unpredictable

definitions: having gotten free from confinement or control
examples: The escaped prisoner was recaptured within hours
An escaped lion roamed the streets

definitions: intended for or understood by only a small group with specialized knowledge
examples: His esoteric references confused most readers
The esoteric ritual required years of study

definitions: better or greater than usual; deserving special emphasis
examples: She took especial care with the fragile items
This matter requires especial attention

definitions: absolutely necessary or extremely important for a particular purpose
relating to the essence or most important qualities of something
examples: Water is essential for human survival
Good communication is essential in relationships
The essential difference lies in their approach
We must focus on essential characteristics

definitions: having been in existence for a long time and therefore recognized
accepted or respected because of having existed for a long period
examples: The established procedure must be followed
She challenged established beliefs
The established company dominated the market
They are an established couple in society

definitions: held in great respect and admiration by others
examples: The esteemed professor received numerous awards
Our esteemed colleague will speak next

definitions: concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty
examples: The esthetic appeal of the design won praise
She made esthetic choices in decorating

definitions: no longer close or affectionate to someone; alienated
examples: His estranged wife filed for divorce
The estranged siblings hadn't spoken in years

definitions: relating to the tidal mouth of a river where it meets the sea
examples: Estuarine ecosystems support diverse wildlife
The estuarine waters mix fresh and salt

definitions: cut or carved into a surface using acid or sharp tools
fixed permanently and deeply in memory or consciousness
examples: The etched glass displayed intricate patterns
Names were etched into the memorial stone
The tragedy remained etched in her memory
Pain was etched on his face

definitions: lasting or existing forever; without end or beginning
examples: Their eternal love inspired many poems
The eternal flame burns at the memorial

definitions: extremely delicate and light in a way that seems not of this world
of or relating to the regions beyond the earth; celestial
examples: Her ethereal beauty captivated the audience
The ethereal music seemed to float through air
The painting depicted ethereal beings
An ethereal glow surrounded the figure

definitions: relating to moral principles or the branch of knowledge dealing with these
examples: The company faces ethical dilemmas about data privacy
Ethical behavior is expected from all employees

definitions: relating to a population group with common national or cultural traditions
examples: The city celebrates its ethnic diversity
Ethnic tensions escalated during the crisis
